Working notes

Acronyms: FAIR (FAIRer; FAIRness) = Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable principles for research data and other digital research objects (e.g., software)

ARDC = Australian Research Data Commons

NeCTAR = National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources

This EOI will focus on the use of LLMs to build a research pipeline (tools, workflows, and techniques) for inductive and abductive disciplines in the humanities, particularly archaeology and history. It aims to ‘catalyze groundbreaking, domain-specific research outcomes from humanities scholars through the integral application of AI-inspired tools and techniques’. 

Brian Ballsun-Stanton, the project lead, (a) is a philosopher of science and technology, (b) has a strong technology background including an advanced degree in IT, (c) is a groundbreaking researcher in the application of LLMs to humanities research and teaching, (d) has worked for over a decade on software development, data modelling, and reproducibility / research confidence in digital humanities, including archaeology, history, ethnography, and linguistics. In much of this work, especially (d), he has collaborated with Shawn Ross.

Shawn Ross, the second applicant, is an archaeologist and historian of SE Europe and Eastern Mediterranean with a specialisation in the development of digital tools and methods. Shawn has let major fieldwork campaigns (including a large-scale, diachronic landscape archaeology project in Bulgaria). He has also led development of field data capture software since 2012 that is still under development and in use. Since 2022 he has also held a secondment to the Australian Research Data Commons, furthering his expertise in persistent identifiers, metadata, vocabularies, and other aspects of FAIR data and research confidence / integrity / reproducibility, which he carries over into his own research and software development. He has collaborated with Brian for over 13 years, and is now working with him on a robust exploration of the use of LLMs to build bibliography and research datasets in a digital humanities / digital archaeology context. As part of his digital archaeology work, he has explored the deployment of digital field recording systems, compared the use of crowdsourcing to automated approaches, and assessed the utility of what would now be considered ‘traditional’ machine-learning approaches to the extraction of archaeological information from remotely sensed imagery (including an exploration of the adoption of these techniques and a critique of their uncritical use and they hype around them). Importantly, as a professor of history and archaeology at Macquarie University seconded to the ARDC as Manager, National Information Infrastructure Products, I connect the participants at Macquarie with those at the ARDC.

In our past collaborations, including around the development of field research software, we have emphasised how working across disciplines - e.g., archaeology, ethnography, oral history, and linguistics in the humanities, plus field sciences like ecology and geoscience - improves our understanding of research design as well as digital tools, techniques, and processes.

The ARDC contribution to the project would include members of the National Coordination unit (including members of the Expertise, Design and Delivery, and Products teams), NeCTAR, and the Humanities, Arts, Social Sciences and Indigenous (HASS&I) Thematics Research Data Commons. These teams have experience with co-design, expertise in AI/ML systems, user-focused product development and delivery, and the implementation of services on a national research cloud, as well as alignment with international best practices in FAIR data, software, and other digital research outputs. Co-development projects at the ARDC generally involve 1:1 co-investment, which is what we request in the budget.

In this application, we intend to explore both capabilities and constraints across the entire research lifecycle of a typical archaeological or historical research project. 

EOI components related to each step of the research lifecycle:

Ideation - iterative exploration of a research topic either for purely inductive research or as the hypothesis-seeking step in abductive research. This step may be iterative, returned to later the hypothesis-seeking phase has been completed to articulate the resulting hypothesis and test criteria to drive the deductive phase of abductive research.  
Articulation of research design, including clear understanding and statement of the type of research, research question or hypothesis, and avoidance of common failures or weaknesses in research design. This step could include approaches like the generation of a preregistration when appropriate to the discipline.
Bibliographic research, including an exploration of what sort of research is returned by ‘deep research’ models (what timeframe, what perspectives, how complete), including whether or not such models tend to emphasise ‘mainstream’ literature or include more idiosyncratic results. 
Dataset generation, cleaning, curation, and documentation. Including multimodal data including structured data, text, geospatial data, and multimedia data as used in, e.g., archaeological research (field and artefact photography; remotely sensed imagery, geospatial feature datasets, historical maps, oral interviews, etc.). (How) can LLMs help assemble research datasets and what are the constraints and limitations? How might these be overcome? LLMs have revolutionised code documentation - (how) can they improve the richness, consistency, and coverage of dataset documentation? How can they improve the machine readability / actionability of datasets, so we can move past human-readable FAIR data to machine-readable FAIR data, as per the original FAIR principles and more recent efforts like WorldFAIR. Discussion of LLMs in improving the FAIRness of data has been limited to date, and it has even been proposed that documenting datasets through metadata may no longer be necessary because LLMs mitigate the need for a discovery / explanatory layer - we believe this outcome is unlikely and LLMs should be seen as a tool for improving documentation. We will also look at how legible datasets are to LLMs and feed this understanding back into the documentation of datasets (as an extension of ‘machine-readability’). Preparation of data for sharing in the mode appropriate to the discipline. 
Software creation, especially how combining a Software Carpentries-level understanding of coding plus the use of LLMs to generate code can allow far more researchers to switch from desktop software like spreadsheets to programmatic analysis, or open programmatic analysis to a wider audience (without ignore the pitfalls and dangers of attempting to use LLMs to generate code when the research does not have adequate knowledge and expertise). This point can apply to quantitative analysis like statistics in archaeology, or to computer assisted text or image analysis. Documentation and FAIRification of software. Preparation of data for sharing in the mode appropriate to the discipline. 
Analysis, such as the development of transparent workflows that can combine data and software to produce analyses that others can understand, replacing irreproducible analyses using (e.g) spreadsheets, GIS tools, or commercial text analysis tools. 
Iterative composition / revision of an output based on this analysis, e.g., incorporating iterative prompting to spur along the writing process through the use of a virtual interlocutor, and improve the structure, thinking, and expression of the paper - without ceding control, losing authorial voice, or being routed into conventional or unoriginal thinking.
Iterating across the steps of this project lifecycle as needed.

The proposed outcome is a pipeline or, more appropriately, a workbench that compliments rather than replaces a human researcher (as opposed to the ‘virtual scientist’ that has sometimes been proposed) that can leverage LLMs to improve scholarly outputs through facilitated ideation, improved research design, FAIRer data, the use of code rather than GUI-based / mass-market software for analysis, and more efficient writing of higher-quality (in terms of structure, logic, and expression) outputs. These improvements will be realised in both qualitative and quantitative research, whether inductive or abductive. 

We would look to implement the components of a workbench in a redeployable way that would allow us to switch out or choose between various models at each stage. We understand that model capabilities are evolving rapidly and are likely to continue doing so over the next 2-3 years, so emphasis will be on effective and reliable techniques, approaches, and tooling that allows the substitution of models for one another for each component of the workbench.

We will leverage the ARDC’s experience in co-design and Product-focused delivery of national (and international) services at a high quality to build a multi-component LLM workbench that could be deployed on the ARDC’s NeCTAR service, developed (and subsequently socialised and promoted) in cooperation with the HASS&I Thematic Research Data Commons and their network of researchers. 

In addition, we will develop approaches to making LLM contributions to research more transparent and reusable, such as capturing chain-of-thought and references in ‘deep research’ / ‘reasoning’ models and agents in a reliable way that can be documented and shared in accordance with the FAIR principles.

We will also include a component to build resources to assist researchers, such as a prompt ‘grimnoire’ and best practices for utilising LLMs in general and with each stage in the research lifecycle / with each component of our workbench.

We are applying for a ‘Medium Award’, defined as ‘Between [USD] $100,001 to $500,000 per year to support research and development that has completed initial phases of planning and is ready to initiate projects that will produce specific, novel outcomes.’

We have already undertaken exploratory research around bibliographic search, dataset generation, software creation, and composition / revision. 

This project would ‘[Explore] AI-based approaches that the field sees as risky, but with high impact if successful’. It aligns with the following priority area:




Budget per year:

Brian, 0.4FTE level D academic, each year = AUD$105,000 = USD$67k
1 x international PhD scholarship for RA (MQRES) = AUD$75,000 = USD$48k
1 x domestic PhD scholarship for RA (MQRES) = AUD$35,000 = USD$23k
Co-investment for ARDC = AUD$400,000 = USD$253k
Total per year = AUD$615k = USD$391k

All items last two years except the PhD scholarships which last three years

Timeline:

Co-design / business analysis / requirements gathering / scoping
Technical elaboration
Iterative development with feedback from users, including QA during development
Deployment of a demonstration service
Continuous improvement through the life of the project implementing a product mindset with a user focus

Dr. Brian Ballsun-Stanton bridges AI theory and practice as the Faculty of Arts' expert in "textual technologies": AI and Digital Humanities at Macquarie University. He offers engaging talks on practical AI applications in research and education, focusing on how to extract everyday utility from these tools while addressing critical ethical considerations. His presentations span from getting mundane, every day, value from AI to developing institutional policies, all delivered with hands-on demonstrations that make complex concepts accessible to any audience. His work on AI integration has earned international recognition, including invited workshops across Australia, Europe, and the US. Contact: brian.ballsun-stanton@mq.edu.au

He can offer a number of workshops, Q&A sessions and keynotes. Ones already prepared are:

"A Hands-on Introduction to Large Language Models like Anthropic's Claude, Microsoft Copilot, and ChatGPT" - A comprehensive 3-hour workshop that teaches the pragmatic realities of these models and how to prompt them effectively. (Ethics of use, prompt "engineering", basic concepts, everyday utility)

"Avoiding Sadness: Research Policy for Generative AI" - An introductory keynote that explores how institutions can develop balanced policies that enable productive AI use while addressing key ethical concerns. (Research policy, misconceptions)

"Research Use of LLMs: Beyond the Chatbot" - A presentation for the Research Data Alliance that demonstrates advanced research applications of LLMs to show how these tools can enhance academic workflows and research processes. (Rapid-fire demo)

"Briefing on the Guidance Note on Generative AI in Research at Macquarie University" - A practical overview of implementing institutional research policies for AI, based on Macquarie University's pioneering guidance framework. (Research policy)

The next three are designed to be presented together:

"Intro and Pragmatics of AI" - A 1 hour session focused on getting practical, everyday value from AI tools with strategies for effective implementation across different disciplines and contexts. (Effective mundane use. Utility for committee work, basic concepts)

"How to Assess Ethics of AI in HREC Applications" - A 2 hour presentation addressing the complex ethical considerations when AI tools are used in human research, with practical guidance for ethics committees and researchers. (Deep dive into risks and issues)

"AI, PICFs, FAIR Data" - A 1 hour exploration of how AI intersects with participant information, consent processes, and FAIR data principles in research contexts. (Transparent use, risk mitigation)

In September, Brian is organising a Technics and Ethics of Generative AI Summer Camp, a collaborative international program hosted by Justus Liebig University Giessen (Germany) in September 2025, bringing together researchers, educators, and students to explore both technical skills and ethical considerations in AI implementation.

He is happy to offer preview sessions (2 hour workshops) of some of the topics that will be covered there:

"Developing Effective Prompts: Structure and Strategy" - A practical workshop, focusing on prompt construction principles and iterative prompt development for achieving more reliable and useful AI outputs. (Mundane utility, basic intro)

"AI as Research Assistant: Basic Theory and Applications" - How to effectively use AI tools for information extraction, organization, and idea development in academic contexts. (Research utility, use, critique, and dangers of "agentic" tools)

"Identifying AI Limitations and Ensuring Quality Outputs" - Teaching participants how to recognize AI confabulation and implement verification strategies. (Risks and benefits)

"Advanced Prompting Techniques and Specialized Applications" - A technical session that demonstrates longer, more thorough prompting approaches and underlying principles for specialized academic use cases. (Tech demo, scripting, and bulk data)

"Working with Multiple AI Models: Comparison and Evaluation" - A comparative analysis workshop that teaches techniques for testing prompts across different AI systems to identify optimal tools for specific tasks. (Benchmarks and evaluations)

"Role-Based Prompting and Scenario Design" - A creative application workshop, demonstrating how to set up specialized AI scenarios for discipline-specific applications including legal, educational, and research contexts. (Simulations, wargames, and interactive applications for future planning and teaching)

(DeepL Translation: The Lernraum.Bauhaus team and the eTeach network
Thuringia[^1] are asking how physical, digital and hybrid spaces can be
designed to optimally support learning and teaching and cordially invite
you to join them in a dialogue about this.

\"Spacing\" here means both designing teaching and learning spaces and
creating connections between them that promote learning. The
digitalisation of teaching and learning formats at universities is
increasingly giving rise to so-called intermediate spaces. These spaces
must be designed in such a way that they enable flexible, participative
and barrier-free learning.

The eTeach annual conference will explore the challenges and potential
of digital, virtual and hybrid spaces and focus on the interplay between
space, technology and didactics. The focus will be on practical examples
and research approaches that show how digital and analogue learning
spaces can be combined creatively and in a way that promotes learning.
The aim is to design \"learning spaces\" together with teachers and
students.)

Information sought:

Keynote: 25 Sept., 1pm

\- duration: 1 hour (40 min. presentation plus intro- and question time)

# **Topis of interest to the E-Teach Netzwerk team (without a narrow alignment to the topic above):**

*\*\*Please indicate which of the following topics align with your
interests and plans (i.e. insert what you have sent me where it aligns,
quick cut-and-paste is okay)*

## - a philosopher's view of LLMS / AI

Yes, absolutely. From a trivial point of view,
<https://denubis.github.io/germany-keynote-ai-policy-briefing/avoiding-sadness#/title-slide>
and my default workshop <https://osf.io/rd24y/> speak to this. Beyond
that, I have a paper: <https://zenodo.org/records/12602858> and more in
process, though most of them are related to the next topic. I have a
paper I'm getting ready to submit to JDoc and present at IACAP:

Abstract 1:

This paper introduces the concept of \"technoscholasticism\" to analyse
fundamental limitations in AI research tools. Through autoethnographic
investigation of frontier models deployed in February 2025, we
demonstrate that these systems, despite claims of \"agentic\"
capabilities, lack three crucial dimensions of judgment: epistemic
humility, inductive capacity, and correspondence with reality. Like
medieval scholastics, these tools privilege textual authority over
critical assessment of knowledge claims, explaining their inability to
generate novel insights despite vast information access. While
acknowledging and testing the current \"mundane utility\" of tools like
Deep Research for specific research tasks, we propose architectural and
methodological requirements for more effective research tools that
acknowledge these inherent constraints and integrate human judgment at
critical junctures. These findings contribute to both theoretical
understanding of AI epistemology and practical approaches to scholarly
tool design.

## - using LLM-based tools in participatory learning and teaching formats (including the course you designed, based on students' interests?)

Papers: <https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s44204-025-00247-1>
and <https://osf.io/preprints/edarxiv/6mke5_v1> plus the papers (plural)
I'm giving for <https://iacapconf.org/2025symposia/teachingAI>

Abstract 2:

This paper examines pedagogical approaches for teaching with and about
AI under conditions of technological uncertainty. Drawing on
Transformative Learning Theory and the Rumsfeld Matrix, we demonstrate
how deliberately decoupling task success from assessment outcomes
creates educational environments where students develop sophisticated AI
intuitions without grade-related inhibitions. Through structured
risk-taking, intentional classroom culture development, and navigation
of \"unknown unknowns,\" students shifted from deferring to AI to
directing it---developing internal AI-Locus of Control. This approach
challenges traditional educational paradigms emphasizing certainty;
instead embracing AI\'s ambiguities as pedagogical opportunities that
foster critical thinking, epistemic humility, and student agency in
technological environments characterized by continual change.

I can also speak to unit details and lessons learned. Plus
implementation in other units (GRMN1020, AHIS1210, etc)

Beyond this, one of the things I'm doing in a "Laws of Armed Conflict
unit" relates to:

\"Role-Based Prompting and Scenario Design\" - A creative application
workshop, demonstrating how to set up specialized AI scenarios for
discipline-specific applications including legal, educational, and
research contexts. (Simulations, wargames, and interactive applications
for future planning and teaching)

## - implementing LLMS-based tools in the curriculum in the context of developing future skills (MQ term: transferable skills?)

So, in the context of the unit I taught, I asked the following questions
of the students:

a\) Identify effective uses of generative AI tools, techniques, and
technologies in the unit so far

b\) Recommend AI tools and techniques for inclusion in a 1st year
\"Techniques of AI\" unit

c\) Suggest AI tools and techniques for a final year \"Capstone with
AI\" unit

d\) Reflect on the mentoring you\'ve provided to teaching staff about
effective AI teaching

And I'd be delighted to present what the students think would be
appropriate for an intro unit and a capstone unit in AI.

I can also speak to the human requirement of judgement.
<https://resobscura.substack.com/p/simulating-history-with-chatgpt> has
a wonderful line I quote all the time: "But the thing is: LLMs are
deeply, inherently textual. And they are reliant on text in a way that
is directly linked to the skills and methods that we emphasize in
university humanities classes." And I can talk about the judgement of
when to use the tool, the textual expertise needed to prompt well and
evaluate the output, and the critical expertise of choosing which sort
of tool to use in which style that are all essential and critical
transferrable skills.

(I've just recently done a 6 hour workshop to the royal Australia New
Zealand College of Ophthalmology\'s HREC committee on these sorts of
questions in an HREC/research guise.)

Yes, I can speak to this in extreme degree, about when to use local
models, the implications of processing, the tedium of reading terms of
service, etc.

# Bio

My bio (<https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4932-7912>) in short is: Dr. Brian
Ballsun-Stanton bridges AI theory and practice as the Faculty of Arts\'
expert in \"textual technologies\": AI and Digital Humanities at
Macquarie University. He offers engaging talks on practical AI
applications in research and education, focusing on how to extract
everyday utility from these tools while addressing critical ethical
considerations. His presentations span from getting mundane, every day,
value from AI to developing institutional policies, all delivered with
hands-on demonstrations that make complex concepts accessible to any
audience. His work on AI integration has earned international
recognition, including invited workshops across Australia, Europe, and
the US.

A longer version is up on the ORCID (as well as my publications.)

# Aarhus details

A 3 week mobility grant to support the teaching of Digital Humanities
and AI. Besides supporting researchers and academics in the use of AI in
their research and units (mostly focusing on the pragmatic and mundane
realities of the situation, rather than grand integrations), the spec
is: "An August \"Summer school on AI for Historians/Social Scientiests\"
and then save the second week for us to work half on assessment and half
on course design, especially comparative quantitative history course
something along the lines of \"West and the rest\", and how can AI help
our novice digital historians get farther with their digital data
cocllection and investigation."

# Giessen details

I will be running the following topics in a "Technics and Ethics of AI
Summer Camp"

\"Developing Effective Prompts: Structure and Strategy\" - A practical
workshop, focusing on prompt construction principles and iterative
prompt development for achieving more reliable and useful AI outputs.
(Mundane utility, basic intro)

\"AI as Research Assistant: Basic Theory and Applications\" - How to
